message_1: Suppose the survival time of a heart transplant patient is normally distributed with mean 8 years and standard deviation 1 year. What is the probability that a randomly selected heart transplant patient will survive for more than 10 years?
message_2:
To find the probability that a randomly selected heart transplant patient will survive for more than 10 years, we can use the z-score formula to standardize the value and then use the standard normal distribution table (or a calculator) to find the probability.

The z-score formula is:

z = (X - μ) / σ

where X is the value we want to find the probability for (10 years), μ is the mean (8 years), and σ is the standard deviation (1 year).

z = (10 - 8) / 1 = 2

Now we need to find the probability that a value from the standard normal distribution is greater than 2. We can use a standard normal distribution table or a calculator to find the area to the right of z = 2.

Using a table or calculator, we find that the area to the left of z = 2 is approximately 0.9772. Since the total area under the curve is 1, the area to the right of z = 2 is:

1 - 0.9772 = 0.0228

So, the probability that a randomly selected heart transplant patient will survive for more than 10 years is approximately 0.0228 or 2.28%.
